expanded_description: This section provides a comprehensive review of all topics covered in Unit 2: 1D Kinematics. It synthesizes the key concepts, formulas, and problem-solving strategies learned throughout the unit, preparing students for assessment and future applications in two-dimensional motion and dynamics.

core_concept.principle: Unit 2 establishes the foundational knowledge of motion in one dimension: describing motion with position, displacement, velocity, and acceleration; interpreting and creating position-time, velocity-time, and acceleration-time graphs; and applying the kinematic equations for constant acceleration to solve problems.
core_concept.explanation: These topics are interconnected. Graphs provide visual insight into motion, with slopes giving rates of change and areas giving accumulated quantities. The kinematic equations are the mathematical tools that quantify these relationships, allowing us to predict and analyze motion in any constant-acceleration situation.

sections.introduction: Unit 2 covered ten sections that build a complete understanding of motion in one dimension. Each topic contributes essential knowledge and skills.

key_concept.definition: One-dimensional kinematics is the study of motion along a straight line, using quantities such as position, displacement, distance, speed, velocity, and acceleration, along with graphical representations and mathematical equations.
key_concept.context: Mastering 1D kinematics is essential for success in later units on two-dimensional motion, forces, energy, and momentum.

characteristics: Motion is relative to a reference point
classifications.behavior: All motion must be described relative to a chosen reference frame. A consistent sign convention (e.g., right/up as positive) must be established and maintained throughout any problem.

examples.explanation: Introduced reference points, frames of reference, and the fundamental vocabulary for describing motion.

classifications.value: Position, displacement, distance, speed, velocity, acceleration
characteristics: Displacement ($\Delta x = x_f - x_i$): change in position (vector)
Speed: rate of change of distance (scalar)
Velocity: rate of change of position (vector)
Acceleration: rate of change of velocity (vector)
classifications.behavior: Scalar quantities (distance, speed) have magnitude only; vector quantities (displacement, velocity, acceleration) have both magnitude and direction, indicated by sign. Velocity changes when speed changes OR direction changes.

examples.explanation: Distinguished between distance (scalar) and displacement (vector).
Distinguished between speed (scalar) and velocity (vector); introduced average and instantaneous values.
Introduced acceleration as rate of change of velocity; distinguished speeding up (v and a same sign) from slowing down (v and a opposite signs).

characteristics: v-t graphs: slope = acceleration, area = displacement
a-t graphs: slope = jerk, area = change in velocity
classifications.behavior: Each graph provides different insights. x-t shows where an object is; v-t shows how fast it's moving and in what direction; a-t shows how velocity is changing. The three are related through slopes and areas.

examples.explanation: Introduced x-t graphs: slope gives velocity; straight lines mean constant velocity; curves mean acceleration.
Introduced v-t graphs: slope gives acceleration; area under curve gives displacement.
Introduced a-t graphs: slope gives jerk; area under curve gives change in velocity.

classifications.behavior: Each equation omits one variable: Eq1 omits $\Delta x$, Eq2 omits $v_f$, Eq3 omits $a$, Eq4 omits $t$. Choose based on known and unknown quantities.

examples.explanation: Introduced the four equations and their derivations.
Applied the equations using a systematic problem-solving strategy.

sections.introduction: This section summarizes the most important concepts from each topic in Unit 2, providing a quick reference for review.

key_concept.definition: Key concepts are the essential ideas that must be understood and remembered from each section.
key_concept.context: These concepts form the foundation for all future studies in mechanics and will be applied repeatedly throughout the course.

principles.statement: Motion is described relative to a reference point (origin). A frame of reference includes a coordinate system and a clock. All motion is relative.
principles.application: Establish a sign convention (e.g., east/right/up positive) before solving any problem.
principles.example: A passenger on a train has different velocities relative to the train and to the ground.

principles.statement: Position ($x$) is location relative to origin. Displacement ($\Delta x = x_f - x_i$) is change in position (vector). Distance is total path length (scalar).
principles.application: Displacement depends only on start and end points; distance depends on path. Displacement can be zero while distance is positive.
principles.example: Walking 10 m east then 10 m west: distance = 20 m, displacement = 0 m.

principles.statement: Speed is distance/time (scalar). Velocity is displacement/time (vector). Average values use total interval; instantaneous values are at a moment.
principles.application: Speed is magnitude of velocity when direction isn't changing. Velocity sign indicates direction.
principles.example: A car going around a curve at constant speed has constant speed but changing velocity (direction changes).

principles.statement: Acceleration is rate of change of velocity: $a = \Delta v / \Delta t$ (vector). Speeding up when $v$ and $a$ have same sign; slowing down when opposite.
principles.application: Acceleration occurs whenever velocity changes – in magnitude, direction, or both. Constant acceleration means velocity changes linearly.
principles.example: A ball thrown upward: on the way up, $v$ positive, $a$ negative → slowing down; on the way down, $v$ negative, $a$ negative → speeding up (in negative direction).

principles.statement: On an x-t graph, slope = velocity. Straight lines mean constant velocity; curves mean acceleration.
principles.application: Positive slope → positive velocity; negative slope → negative velocity; horizontal line → at rest ($v=0$).
principles.example: A straight line with slope 5 m/s means constant velocity of 5 m/s.

principles.statement: On a v-t graph, slope = acceleration; area under curve = displacement.
principles.application: Positive slope → positive acceleration; negative slope → negative acceleration; horizontal line → constant velocity ($a=0$). Area above axis positive, below negative.
principles.example: A triangle under a v-t line from rest gives displacement $\frac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}$.

principles.statement: On an a-t graph, slope = jerk (rarely used); area under curve = change in velocity ($\Delta v$).
principles.application: Horizontal line → constant acceleration; area above axis positive, below negative. $v_f = v_i + \text{area}$.
principles.example: A rectangle of height 2 m/s² for 3 s gives $\Delta v = 6$ m/s.

principles.statement: Four equations describe constant acceleration motion. Each omits one variable.
principles.application: List knowns and unknowns; choose equation omitting the variable not given/needed.
principles.example: Given $v_i$, $a$, $t$, find $\Delta x$: use $\Delta x = v_i t + \frac{1}{2}at^2$.

principles.statement: Follow a systematic strategy: diagram, sign convention, list knowns/unknowns, select equation, substitute, solve, check.
principles.application: Watch for implied values (starts from rest → $v_i=0$; comes to stop → $v_f=0$). Convert units to be consistent.

sections.introduction: Unit 2 introduced several formulas and mathematical relationships that are essential for solving kinematics problems.

key_concept.definition: Formulas are mathematical expressions that describe relationships between physical quantities. Understanding when and how to use each formula is essential.
key_concept.context: These formulas appear repeatedly in future units on two-dimensional motion, forces, and energy. Memorize them and practice applying them.

characteristics: Instantaneous velocity: slope of x-t graph
Instantaneous acceleration: slope of v-t graph
classifications.behavior: These definitions are always true, even when acceleration is not constant. They are the starting point for deriving other relationships.

examples.explanation: If displacement is 50 m in 2 s, $v_{avg} = 25$ m/s.

classifications.behavior: These equations are valid ONLY when acceleration is constant. They are derived from the definitions and the constant acceleration assumption.

examples.explanation: Find final velocity given $v_i = 10$ m/s, $a = 2$ m/s², $t = 4$ s: $v_f = 10 + 2(4) = 18$ m/s.
Find stopping distance: $v_i = 20$ m/s, $a = -5$ m/s², $v_f = 0$: $0 = 20^2 + 2(-5)\Delta x$ → $\Delta x = 400/10 = 40$ m.

characteristics: a-t graph area = change in velocity
classifications.behavior: These relationships allow translation between graphical and algebraic representations of motion.

examples.explanation: On x-t, slope 3 m/s means velocity 3 m/s.
On v-t, area 40 m means displacement 40 m.

characteristics: At highest point of upward throw, $v = 0$
classifications.behavior: All objects in free fall (ignoring air resistance) have the same downward acceleration $g$, regardless of mass.

examples.explanation: $v_i = 0$, $a = +9.8$ (down positive), $\Delta x = \frac{1}{2}gt^2$
$v_i$ positive (up), $a = -9.8$ (up positive), at top $v=0$, $t_{top} = v_i/g$, height $= v_i^2/(2g)$

sections.introduction: Reviewing common errors from each section helps prevent them in future work.

characteristics: Using wrong sign for acceleration (e.g., $g$ positive when up is positive)
classifications.behavior: Sign errors lead to wrong direction or magnitude. Always write down your sign convention first and stick to it.

examples.explanation: For upward throw, using $a = +9.8$ m/s² with up positive → ball accelerates upward forever.
With up positive, $a = -9.8$ m/s².

classifications.value: Using distance when displacement is needed (or vice versa)
characteristics: Using total path length for average velocity
Not recognizing that displacement can be zero while distance is positive
classifications.behavior: Average velocity uses displacement; average speed uses distance. Mixing them gives wrong answers.

examples.explanation: Round trip 100 m each way in 50 s: student calculates velocity = 200/50 = 4 m/s.
Displacement = 0, so velocity = 0 m/s; speed = 200/50 = 4 m/s.

classifications.value: Confusing slope and area, or misreading graph features
characteristics: On v-t, using slope for displacement
On x-t, thinking slope is acceleration
classifications.behavior: Each graph has specific relationships: x-t slope = v; v-t slope = a, area = Δx; a-t area = Δv.

examples.explanation: On v-t, student calculates area and calls it acceleration.
Area under v-t is displacement; slope is acceleration.

classifications.value: Choosing an equation with too many unknowns
characteristics: Not listing knowns and unknowns first
Using equation that includes an unknown that isn't given
classifications.behavior: This leads to unsolvable equations. Use the list-and-omit method to select the correct equation.

examples.explanation: Given $v_i$, $v_f$, $a$, asked for $\Delta x$, but using $\Delta x = v_i t + \frac{1}{2}at^2$ (needs $t$).
Use $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$ (no $t$).

characteristics: Using minutes without converting to seconds
classifications.behavior: Equations require consistent units. Convert everything to SI (m, s, m/s, m/s²) before substituting.

examples.explanation: $v_i = 60$ km/h, $a = 2$ m/s², $t = 5$ s → plugging directly gives nonsense.
Convert 60 km/h to 16.67 m/s first.

classifications.value: Overlooking implied values like 'starts from rest' ($v_i=0$) or 'comes to a stop' ($v_f=0$)
classifications.behavior: These implied values provide crucial knowns. Underline them in the problem statement.

examples.explanation: Object dropped from height: student forgets $v_i=0$.
'Dropped' means $v_i=0$.

sections.introduction: These practice problems review key skills from Unit 2. Work through them to check your understanding.

worked_examples.title: Kinematic Equations
worked_examples.problem: A car accelerates uniformly from 15 m/s to 25 m/s over a distance of 200 m. Find (a) the acceleration and (b) the time taken.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Use appropriate equations sequentially when multiple unknowns exist.

worked_examples.title: Graph Interpretation
worked_examples.problem: A velocity-time graph shows a line from (0 s, 10 m/s) to (4 s, 2 m/s). (a) Find the acceleration. (b) Find the displacement during this interval.

step_by_step.explanation: Area under trapezoid = average height × width = $\frac{10+2}{2} \times 4 = 6 \times 4 = 24$ m

worked_examples.concept_applied: On v-t graphs, slope = acceleration, area = displacement.

worked_examples.title: Free Fall
worked_examples.problem: A stone is thrown downward with an initial speed of 5 m/s from a cliff 50 m high. (a) How long does it take to hit the ground? (b) What is its velocity just before impact? (Use $g = 9.8$ m/s², down positive.)

step_by_step.step: Find time using $\Delta x = v_i t + \frac{1}{2}at^2$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Free fall problems use same equations with $a = g$ (sign consistent with convention).

worked_examples.title: Two-Object Problem
worked_examples.problem: A student runs at constant 4 m/s toward a bus stop 100 m away. At the instant she starts running, a bus begins accelerating from rest toward the same stop from the opposite direction, 80 m away on the other side, with acceleration 1 m/s². Do they meet? If so, where?

step_by_step.explanation: Let the bus stop be at $x=0$. Student starts at $x = +100$ m running toward stop (negative direction) at $v_s = -4$ m/s. Bus starts at $x = -80$ m moving toward stop (positive direction) from rest with $a_b = +1$ m/s².

worked_examples.final_answer: They meet at $t = 15.4$ s at $x = 38.4$ m (on the student's side of the stop)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Set position equations equal to find meeting time; choose consistent coordinate system.

summary: Unit 2: 1D Kinematics established the fundamental concepts and tools for analyzing motion along a straight line. We learned that motion is described relative to a reference frame with a consistent sign convention. Key quantities include position ($x$), displacement ($\Delta x = x_f - x_i$), distance, speed (scalar), velocity ($\vec{v} = \Delta x/\Delta t$, vector), and acceleration ($\vec{a} = \Delta v/\Delta t$, vector). Graphs provide visual insight: position-time graphs give velocity as slope; velocity-time graphs give acceleration as slope and displacement as area; acceleration-time graphs give change in velocity as area. For constant acceleration, four kinematic equations relate the variables: $v_f = v_i + at$, $\Delta x = v_i t + \frac{1}{2}at^2$, $\Delta x = \frac{v_i + v_f}{2}t$, and $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$. A systematic problem-solving strategy is essential: draw a diagram, establish sign convention, list knowns and unknowns, select the appropriate equation (omitting the unnecessary variable), substitute with consistent units, solve, and check for reasonableness. Special cases include free fall ($a = g = 9.8$ m/s² downward), braking to stop ($v_f = 0$), multi-stage motion (treat each segment separately), and two-object problems (equate position equations). Common mistakes include sign errors, confusing distance and displacement, misinterpreting graphs, choosing wrong equations, unit inconsistencies, and overlooking implied conditions. Mastering these foundations is essential for success in two-dimensional kinematics and dynamics.
